byline.original: By MIREYA NAVARRO and C. J. HUGHES

abstract: New York City's Rent Guidelines Board votes on potential rent increases for city's rent-stabilized apartments; two-year leases could rise 0.5 percent to 3.5 percent when body holds final vote, while one-year leases could be frozen or rise up to 2 percent; panel faces dissent from boisterous crowd and some members who demand freezes.
lead_paragraph: Possible rent increases this year for the city’s rent-stabilized apartments will run up to 3.5 percent, according to a vote by members of the Rent Guidelines Board.

headline.main: Rent-Stabilized Tenants in New York City Renew Call for a Freeze
headline.print_headline: Rent-Stabilized Tenants Renew Call for a Freeze

snippet: Possible rent increases this year for the city’s rent-stabilized apartments will run up to 3.5 percent, according to a vote by members of the Rent Guidelines Board.
